awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Helium-Jet Ion-Guide System for Harvesting Rare Isotopes and Commensal Operation at NSCL
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) is the nation's premier facility to accelerate nuclei with the purpose of studying nuclear structure.  NSCL has developed world-unique new experimental capabilities with reaccelerated rare-isotope beams, ensuring a continued leadership role in rare-isotope physics worldwide. With the recent expansion of research capabilities at NSCL, demand for these beams to be used in nuclear physics experiments has never been higher. The instrument proposed here, called a Helium-Jet Ion Gas System (HJ-IGS) will allow for commensal running of two experiments simultaneously, each using different detector systems at NSCL, which will expand the number of experiments and hence help to meet the demand for experiments that increase our understanding of nuclei.

Helium-Jet Ion Sources have been used for harvesting isotopes in the past, but the idea to use such a system to harvest some of the rarest isotopes available to researchers in a projectile fragmentation facility is novel. Rare isotopes that are bent out of the central beam path during the purification process of the primary rare-isotope beam are stopped and collected in a high-pressure cell filled with Helium saturated with aerosols to which the stopped isotopes will attach. With a high-pressure differential, the collected isotopes are quickly transported through a 40 meter-long capillary to an ion source that injects the isotopes, after purification, into a beam line that can feed one of several stations not used in the primary experiment. This allows two experiments to be performed at the same time: an experiment using a fast rare isotope beam directly produced in projectile fragmentation and an experiment with stopped or reaccelerated beams using the harvested, transported, ionized and purified isotopes in the HJ-IGS. State-of-the-art experiments that are in high demand in the fields of nuclear structure and nuclear astrophysics, as well as fundamental interactions and symmetries, and include such diverse techniques as high-precision mass measurements in atom traps, in-beam laser spectroscopy and polarization, nuclear decay spectroscopy, and low-energy reaction studies with an active-target time projection chamber.

por.por_cntn:
The production and study of unstable (or "rare") isotopes provides access to information on isotopes that is important for the understanding the fundamental nature of matter, nuclear reactions that take place in astronomical scenarios and that, for example, produced the matter earth was created from, and applications that benefit society, for example through medical diagnostics and treatments. The production of rare isotopes, especially the ones that decay to more stable isotopes quickly, is difficult and costly. At the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) at Michigan State University (MSU), rare isotopes are produced by impinging an intense beam of stable isotopes travelling at ~40% of the speed of light on a production target. A wide variety of rare isotopes are then produced through fragmentation of the incoming stable isotopes. By using a fragment separator for selecting rare isotopes of interest for a particular study, a beam of these isotopes is delivered to one of several experimental end stations. In the present configuration, the beam can only be delivered to one end station at a time, even though requests for beams and experimental time is very high. In addition, some isotopes that are very desirable for experiments are produced but not used and lost for research opportunities.

The goal of the Helium-Jet Ion-Guide System (HJ-IGS) project was aimed at developing a system for collecting the unused rare isotopes and delivering them to a secondary experimental station for use in another experiment. Consequently, it is possible to perform simultaneously two experiments with short-lived rare-isotopes. This is particularly important since much more intense rare isotopes beams will become available at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) at MSU, creating vastly new scientific and societal benefits.  The HJ-IGS will provide additional experimental opportunities with the unique isotopes that FRIB will produce.

The HJ-IGS is based on a relatively simple technique: the stopping of the unused rare isotopes in a high-pressure gas cell. The gas cell is placed at the end of the fragment separator, where the isotopes of interest for the primary experiment are displaced by a small distance (about 1 inch) from the beam of interest for the second experiment. Therefore, the cell can be inserted to stop the isotopes for the second experiment without disturbing those for the first experiment. Gas is continuously circulated through the cell and the gas is also saturated with aerosols. The rare isotopes stopped in the cell attach to the aerosols and are transported over a distance of about 70 feet through a thin tube. At the end of the tube, the isotopes are removed from the aerosols in a skimmer, and are available for experiments, if necessary after additional beam transport.

The HJ-IGS system used for the project was originally developed at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL). The project focused on the transport, installation, and testing of the system at NSCL at MSU. The project benefited from consultation from experts at ORNL, Rutgers University, and Texas A&M University. A schematic overview of the systems is shown in Figure 1. The HJ-IGS was also prepared for experiments with the SuN detector system, a highly efficient detector for gamma radiation that enables fore-front science with the HJ-IGS.

A test experiment focused on the transport of unstable isotopes of Arsenic (Arsenic-70) and Germanium (Germanium-69) from the stopping cell placed at the exit of the NSCL fragments separator to the HJ-IGS. A gamma spectrum measured from isotopes collected in the HJ-IGS is shown in Figure 2. The peaks are associated with the decay of Arsenic-70 and Germanium-69, demonstrating the ability of the system to stop and transport rare isotopes to a second experimental station. The completed system now awaits its use at the nearly completed Facility for Rare Isotope Beams at MSU.
